entry.title: My first npm project: react-a11y-select
entry.content:
I’ve had a interest/passions/fascination with web accessibility (a11y) ever since I worked at my previous employer, Sigient (note: they might be out of business now, and that site appears to be down). That particular job was a consulting company, and I ended up on the staff augmentation side of the business, which wasn’t particularly awesome, but I’ll save that story for another time.

Anyhow, I was working with one of the major nationwide internet service providers in the United States. They too are no longer in business, as they’ve been recently acquired. One of the things I took on was converting some major swaths of their customer portal (an old Backbone web application) to instead use React. While I was in the middle of that task, the company had come under pressure to quickly make their customer portal accessible to users with disabilities. I have no idea where this pressure was coming from – there were rumors of a lawsuit, but this was hearsay and I have no idea if there was any truth to that.

I had very little exposure to web accessibility at that point in my career. In retrospect, it’s shameful that this is the case, but I don’t believe it’s uncommon. I’ve been developing websites for well over 15 years, and never had I encountered a situation where anyone made accessibility a priority. Because of that, I knew next to nothing about roles or aria attributes, web-accessible color palettes, or the imporatance of using semantic elements and design to ensure that screen readers would be able to interpret pages that I’ve been responsible for.

Since my experience at Sigient, I’ve made a conscious effort to apply accessibility to my designs whenever I’ve been afforded the opportunity. As I’ve transitioned to doing a lot more front-end work, particularly in React, it’s become clear that we have an opportunity to reduce the difficulty in building accessible rich internet applicaitons. Because React (and many of the other new Javascript frameworks) are component-based, component builders can focus on making their individual components accessible, while application developers can use off-the-shelf components which have been tested and meet minimum a11y guidelines.

This obviously requires buy-in from component developers, but I’m optimistic that component based UI architecture will make this possible and achievable.

react-a11y-select

To that end, I’ve started a project on npm to build a web-accessible select component. The first rule of accessibility is to use native components whenever possible. However, over the course of my career I’ve seen many designs requiring select/dropdown components with styled options containing graphics and other elements. With this project I’m hoping to make doing so in an accessible way super-simple.

I just started this project recently, and it doesn’t even meet all the accessibility guidelines yet. It’s not as performant as I’d like. It’s missing some key features that I want to add. But it’s a start and it’s my very first npm project, and first component library. I hope to keep plugging away at it, and introduce more components as I get better at this (I’m thinking I might do Radio buttons next!).

Here’s a link to the project on Github and on npm.

Feel free to submit pull requests. :)
